rComments: Linda is a great lecturer and you will learn so much. This is the hardest class I've taken, but you shouldn't believe the fearmongering on this page. If you take the class seriously and study hard, you should pass. If you must get an A take it somewhere else. You cannot start studying a couple days before the midterms, you will straight up fail.

Linda is  the most down to earth profs I've ever had! Go to her office hours and just talk to her if you get a chance! Her class is very difficult but go to ALL the lectures! She podcast them but don't count on that because you will need to hear stuff more than once. Also read the book and know the material inside and out. Very difficult tests.

Linda is super knowledgable and welcomes all questions about anything she lectures about. Read the book, take your own notes, write down everything she says in lecture and actively listen to every single word she says. Memorize everything you possibly can and you will be able to apply it on the tests. Only the MCAT was harder than her exams FYI...

I admit, I love Linda. I took every class she offered, and while I may have studied harder than any other class, I learned so much applicable information. She is by far the best. You must attend her office hours because she is the sweetest and is extremely personable. Best way to study for 130 was in small groups and using USMLE Q-banks.

Linda is the nicest professor you'll ever meet,and then she'll give you post doctorate exams and expect you to think like a doctor. Her final, which is worth 50%, was impossibly difficult and long. Don't spend a second doing her calculation problems because you'll probably get zeroes on every single one because they're unlike what she taught.

Attend class, write down lectures after class (verbatim), and read the book. It also helps to talk about things with friends just so that you can say things out loud. You will have try, but it's possible!
great lecturer. horrible tests. lecture does not prepare you at all for the tests. have to know the topic inside and out

Very difficult course. Her lectures don't teach at a level that will prepare you for exams. Exams are extremely difficult. Averages were in the 50's% for both midterms.  She's very nice, approachable & available outside of class, but doesn't mean she will really help. Take somewhere else w/ more realistic expectations if you want to get an A.

Tests were super hard. Reading the book plus listening to the podcasts after lecture really helped. Find a study buddy to bounce ideas off of, helps you understand the concepts. Give this class your all, and take the lab during the class, it totally helps you understand the concepts more.

Linda is a born lecturer and you will leave the class with a ton more knowledge than before, given that you have the slightest of interest in endo. That said, she the hardest prof I have ever had, with the toughest & most relentless exams ever. Put the time it & it'll be worth it - don't and you will be struggling to pass...

Mammalian Endocrinology is extremely tedious and time consuming -if you don't give each midterm your all you wont stand a chance on the final-which is cumulative. Despite how hard this course was Ogren was an amazing teaching and always had nothing but positive things to say. I wouldn't have passed without going to her office hours.

Possibly the hardest bio class offered. If you stay on track, go to every section, and above all, TRY, you can get an A. Anything less, you will crash and burn. New material builds upon old, so keep up. Linda is awesome, material is awesome. Don't take this if you're semi-interested.

Ogren is a wonderful person and and has been by far the best professor at UC Santa Cruz. She really knows her stuff and can teach it to perfection. However, if you plan on taking this class, or any with her, stay up to date and put in A LOT of effort from the BEGINNING! For her exams be as detailed and specific as possible.

Teaches at a CP Biology level from high school and administers post-medical school examinations.  STAY AWAY IF YOU CAN.  Is on a power trip if you ask most people.  Average fail rate each term is about 66%.

Linda is by far the best professor at UCSC.  She is extremely approachable and always willing to answer any questions you may have.  Her exams are very difficlt, but always fair and only consist of information she puts on the topic lists that she posts.  Don't let the rumors of Linda scare you away from the course, easily my fav class and professor

One of the hardest classes I've ever taken. Linda is an amazing teacher who actually cares about her students. The knowledge expected for her tests is way more detailed than her lectures, but duh: lectures are only an hour long. She doesn't just want you to master her class-- she wants you to master physiology. And she's always willing to help.

Honest Breakdown on her: It's a make or break class. During the lecture she teaches well and answers your questions. She wants you to do well. However, on her tests it a different story. She expects you to apply the knowledge you learned in a paragraph format. You won't have enough time, and she nitpicks on any missing details. High 75-85 is an A.
The tests would not be difficult if she taught the class at the same level.  Instead she condescends all concepts simplifies them to a point that becomes useless for the test.
Endo is a difficult class, but Ogren is a wonderful person and wants you to do well.  She's very sweet and she truely cares about her students.
People feel Ogren is too difficult... this is an upper-division college course. Duh! Record her lectures and copy  her notes verbatim.  I promise you'll pass.

she will rip you a new one. she tears apart your reports for no reason, makes no sense during lecture, and gives ridiculous quizzes you can't study for. she is super nice though, but it doesn't help the fact that you can be a straight A student and still get a C in her class. avoid her - go with Dalbey.
She's nice.

Tests are insanely difficult but her lectures are interesting and the material is engaging. Must study like none-other. Great woman, very helpful especially during office hours and lab. Tries her hardest to explain difficult concepts, even if it's beyond comprehension.
a great teacher. she does give hard tests though, but she's engaging in lecture, and super helpful during office hours.
oh, those hours that i've spent with linda... only to still not understand what was going on...

I took this woman for bio 20L and I was very disappointed. She seemed to know the subject very well but overall the class was poorly constructed. E.g., she gave pop-quizes when she said she wouldn't--whose subject matter, by the way,was hardly covered in lecture or in print. STAY AWAY!!

Concentrates more on fact memorization than students gaining a true and deep understanding of the material - not conducive to long term learning or knowledge transfer.  Lectures about interesting topics become boring and tedious.

This woman knows her physiology. If you like phys, you'll like her. She is very detail oriented and her tests are difficult. If you put effort into the class you'll really leave having learned a lot, especially in endocrinology (bio113).

Seems like a nice lady, but can't lecture that well, although her handouts and diagrams were helpful.  Pretty boring, and her test was terrible - she didn't even write it herself or curve it and it was tricky.  I heard Ingrid Parker is much better for 20b
she knows her material and explains it well. exams arent the easiest but they are fair.
No Comments

Her tests wouldn't be hard if she knew how to teach. She rambles for 3/4 of class on unrelated stuff & spends the rest scrawling confusing notes in her terrible handwriting. If you miss class, you're screwed because she uses a very buggy video recording of her lectures that only seems to work on her computer.

Linda is an amazing professor, but her exams are quite difficult.  She is able to take the most difficult concepts and make them easy enough for anyone to understand - even for people who find science difficult.  I would recommend her classes any day, but be prepared to spend more time studying for her class than anyone else's that quarter.

Very organized lectures with matching reading that is well outlined. Tests are very difficult and require you to know how to analyze problems not just regurgitate things you memorized. Know how to explain/order everything she mentions in class or tells you to read about in her outlines!

A teacher who condescends to her students with each lecture.  Fine if <20 y.o. but mature people find it rude and disrespectful.  Tests at a professional level but the lectures are treated as if the students are still in High School with a matching comprehension level.  This mismatch of teaching makes students unprepared for exams. (I got an A-)

Linda is by far one of the best teachers I've had. I am positive that every one of these complaints are from people who are bitter they did poorly. Yes, her tests are hard, and she obviously expects a lot out of her students, which is refreshing at UCSC (though apparently many students are spoiled and whiny from all the easy profs).

She is a very good professor and explains things well. The problem is your entire grade is on tests so, if you bomb one, best to withdraw. Only take the class if you are into biology or majoring in it since you have to commit to the class. Be sure to study lecture notes and the text for exams.

Linda is a very approachable professor. Her class was interesting, but her tests were insanely difficult. I tried so hard for that class, went to her office hours more than twice a week, and still didn't get above a C. I would avoid taking it with her, it's probably wiser to take it elsewhere if you want to keep your GPA.

This is a really tough class so make sure you keep up with the material and readings.  I never went to her office hours, but I wish I did.  You need a 55% overall to pass.  2 midterms were 25% each and the final was worth 50%.  She is very approachable.  The only downside is that she's a nit-picky grader.  I def learned a lot in this class.
Take good notes! Her exams come straight from all what she writes and says. I wrote down every word that came out of her and that is how i got A on my exams. She is also really nice person.

Her tests are literally terror inducing and impossible; I'm a senior, I've passed harder classes, this one was ridiculous, especially if you're in any other science course.  I love physiology but she has temporarily ruined the topic for me. Her tests come out of nowhere.  She WILL test you on thing from the book that she did NOT go over in class.

Linda is a born lecturer. She teaches extremely difficult material in a comprehensible manner and makes sure you understand what she's saying. However, she tests in a problem-based learning manner which is not always identical to her presentation. You will need to go a bit above and beyond in this course. Stay on guard & you'll make it. Take it once first P/NP, if possible.

Horrible teacher, tests are above and beyond what she teaches in class and she is such an absent minded prof, that she would constantly tell us things only to tell us the the next lecture that she was wrong and confused this with that or some other BS about why she screwed up.  It's terrible she's still around.

She is a great lecturer and is incredibly organized in her approach to teaching body systems. Her exams are a challenge and you have to be able to apply the concepts learned. Doing the outlines she provides were very helpful.

This class is taught to be very applicable to a clinical setting (problem based).  Flashcards will not suffice.  If you want to pass, imagine yourself with a human patient.  If you plan on attending med school and struggle with her tests, rethink your studying habits.

WORST teacher ever.  i dropped her class before she had the pleasure in failing me or ruining my GPA, I currently have an A+++ in the human physiology class i am taking somewhere else, and by far know my stuff very well.

I have never ever studied so hard for a class, and her tests were still nearly impossible. She expects us to know every detail as well as being able to apply the mechanisms. The test questions were complicated and half the time you are trying to figure out what she's asking. She was a good teacher, but expects too much from us,Lots of people failed

Quite possibly the worst class because of the teacher.  She takes a subject that should be fun and interesting, and makes it difficult and frustrating.  Her exams are the reason this class was so difficult.  If you take this class, do the homework problems in the back of the chapters, and go to office hours as much as possible.

This teacher is another reason why I ask myself, "why can't there be good teachers at UCSC." She is an awful lecturer, and a nit-picky grader.  Human physiology is not a hard subject, but her tests are made to ruin you.  I wish she would be fired.  She should look at the 50% average on the exams and ask herself whether she is doing something wrong

She was my favorite teacher at UCSC! She is very clear, and cares a lot about student progress. She requires a lot of her students, but if you are willing to put in the effort her classes are great and you learn a ton! I took physiology and endocrinology and wish I could have taken more of her classes!
hard tests. kind of sets you up for failure. she teaches you mechanisms but tests you on application. i suggest taking it elsewhere or studying hella hard.
